thread.title: 9 inspirational books top CEOs want you to read

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 9 inspirational books top CEOs want you to read
text:
Mark Lennihan/AP Check out these books recommended by top CEOs, and download them on your e-reader. What do CEO's like to read on their downtime when they're not busy trying to improve the world?
Well, many of them avidly read books to better themselves, proving that hours curled up on the couch with an e-reader can be a great way to wind down after a long day.
Some statistics show that company bosses read four to five books per month — which is four to five times higher the number of books an average person reads in a year, according to Refresh Leadership .

Below is a hodgepodge of favorite books of some of the top CEOs in the country.
Recommended readings range from business reference books to self-help guides. But the list also includes science fiction novels.
Check it out for yourself:
Beta Nu Publishing 'The Foundation Trilogy' by Isaac Asimov. Picador 'The Checklist Manifesto' by Atul Gawande Basic Books 'The Design of Everyday Things' by Don Norman Open Road Integrated Media LLC 'Business Adventures' John Brooks Free Press 'Competing Against Time' by George Stalk Jr. and Thomas M. Hout HarperCollins Publishers 'The Innovator's Dilemma' by Clayton M. Christensen. Basic Books 'The end of Power' by Moises Naim. Penguin Publishing Group 'The Boys in the Boat: Nine Americans and Their Epic Quest for Gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics' by Daniel James Brown. Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group Jeff Bezos' 'The Remains of the Day' Previous Next Enlarge 1. "The Remains of the Day," by Kazuo Ishiguro
"If you read 'The Remains of the Day,' which is one of my favorite books, you can't help but come away and think, I just spent 10 hours living an alternate life and about regret," Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos, who apparently bought 10 books a month , told Newsweek in a 2009 interview.
2. "The Boys in the Boat: Nine Americans and Their Epic Quest for Gold at the 1936 Olympics," by Daniel James Brown
Besides having an affinity for reading spy novels like "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" and Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy" by John le Carre, Morgan Stanley's chairman and CEO, James Gorman, is inspired by Brown's novel about a team of U.S. rowers who persevered at the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin.
3. "The End of Power," by Moises Naim
Facebook co-founder and chief Mark Zuckerberg started a New Year's resolution of reading a new book every other week in 2015, with his first choice being a political study by renowned columnist and commentator, Moisés Naím.
"The End of Power" reveals the meaning of leadership in business, politics, education, religion, and family, and how it has changed over the past century.
4. "The Innovator's Dilemma," by Clayton Christensen
In 2005 , the late Steve Jobs told Stanford University seniors to "Stay hungry. Stay foolish."
Clayton Christensen's " The Innovator's Dilemma ," a book about emerging technologies and how they have made an impact on top companies, deeply influenced the former Apple CEO.
5. "Competing Against Time," by George Stalk
Stalk's classic about why time is money in business is Apple CEO Tim Cook's favorite book of all-time.
Cook sometimes hands copies of "Competing Against Time" to his colleagues and is a suggested reading for new hires.
6. "Business Adventures," by John Brooks
This collection of New Yorker anecdotes became Bill Gates' favorite business book after Warren Buffett recommended it and sent the Microsoft co-founder a copy.
Gates said that the book reminds entrepreneurs that the principles for a winning business remain constant, according to Business Insider.
7. "The Design of Everyday Things," by Donald A. Norman
Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer told Little PINK Book in an interview that this was her favorite book.
"I think a lot about design and products and how things should work," Mayer said in the interview.
"But it makes you notice things that can be infuriating. Like, why does my sandwich shop have meat all the way over there? At the same time, it makes you think about design in new ways, because when you use something everyday it needs to be absolutely efficient and not get in your way. It's cool to be able to articulate and discuss that on a level that is really accessible and interesting."
8. "The Checklist Manifesto: How to Get Things Right," by Atul Gawande
Like Cook, Twitter CEO and Square founder Jack Dorsey gives copies of his favorite book to new employees as part of their welcome kit.
Dorsey likes to Quote: from the "The Checklist Manifesto," especially the passage about venture capitalists picking the right startup companies to invest in.
9. "The Foundation Trilogy," by Isaac Asimov
Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla Motors, is a bit different from the others, choosing Asimov's epic science fiction series.
"In terms of sci-fi books, I think Isaac Asimov is really great," he said, according to Pinax .
"I like the Foundation series, probably one of the all-time best."
